discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. A full, weekly backup with daily differential backups.

Selected Answer: D
Keyword "restore": Incremental will "backup" quicker than Differential, but will "restore" slower, ergo quickest option is D.

Selected Answer: D
D. A full, weekly backup with daily differential backups

Differential backups capture all changes made since the last full backup. By performing a full backup of the accounting server every seven days and then creating daily differential backups, you ensure that you have a comprehensive backup of all modified data since the last full backup.

When restoring the server data, you only need to restore the last full backup and the latest differential backup. This minimizes the restore time compared to other backup types because you only need to apply the latest differential backup to the full backup to bring the data up to date.

Selected Answer: D
To restore a full backup as quickly as possible in the event of a complete loss of server data, you would want to minimize the number of backup sets you need to restore. Given the options:

D. A full, weekly backup with daily differential backups

This would be the best choice. With differential backups, each backup contains all the changes since the last full backup. So, in the event of a complete loss, you would only need to restore the latest full backup and the latest differential backup. If you were using incremental backups, you would need to restore the full backup and every incremental backup since the last full backup, which would take longer.

Selected Answer: C
Only backing up modified data on a daily basis. Must be incremental.

questions.question_text: A change in policy requires a complete backup of the accounting server every seven days and a backup of modified data every day. Which of the following would be BEST to restore a full backup as quickly as possible in the event of a complete loss of server data?

choices.C: A full, weekly backup with daily incremental backups
choices.A: A full, weekly backup with daily open-file backups
choices.D: A full, weekly backup with daily differential backups
choices.B: A full, weekly backup with daily archive backups

questions.question_text: An administrator has been asked to increase the storage capacity of a stand-alone file server, but no further expansion slots are available. Which of the following would be the FASTEST solution to implement with no downtime?

choices.B: Replace the current drives with higher-capacity disks.
choices.D: Connect the server to a SAN.
choices.C: Implement FCoE for more storage capacity.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Connect the server to a SAN

Connecting the server to a SAN would allow the administrator to expand the storage capacity without downtime by adding additional storage resources from the SAN to the file server without needing to physically replace disks or disrupt server operations. The SAN can provide additional storage capacity without requiring the server to be taken offline. This solution offers scalability and flexibility in expanding storage capacity while minimizing downtime.
Key word is no downtime. A and C are irelevant, and B would cause downtime. D makes most sense here.

questions.question_text: A Linux server was recently updated. Now, the server stops during the boot process with a blank screen and an fs> prompt. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this issue?

choices.A: The system is booting to a USB flash drive.
choices.D: The BIOS firmware needs to be upgraded.
choices.B: The UEFI boot was interrupted by a missing Linux boot file.
choices.C: The BIOS could not find a bootable hard disk.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. The UEFI boot was interrupted by a missing Linux boot file.

This is the most likely cause. If the UEFI firmware cannot find the EFI boot loader for Linux (e.g., grubx64.efi or shimx64.efi in the EFI System Partition), it may drop to the UEFI shell (fs>) instead of booting the operating system.

When a Linux server stops during the boot process with a blank screen and an fs> prompt, this indicates that the system has entered the UEFI Shell. This usually occurs when the UEFI firmware cannot find a valid boot device or boot file to load the operating system. The fs> prompt is a typical UEFI file system shell prompt, suggesting that the issue is related to UEFI and the boot process.

choices.B: Connect a console cable to the server NIC.
choices.A: Connect the diagnostic card to the PCIe connector.
choices.C: Connect to the server from a crash cart.

questions.question_text: A server technician arrives at a data center to troubleshoot a physical server that is not responding to remote management software. The technician discovers the servers in the data center are not connected to a KVM switch, and their out-of-band management cards have not been configured. Which of the following should the technician do to access the server for troubleshooting purposes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Connect to the server from a crash cart.

C. Connect to the server from a crash cart.
What i usually do first to investigate. From here i go to Putty or SMTK if problem is more complex.

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes a configuration in which both nodes of a redundant system respond to service requests whenever possible?

discussion.content:
A is correct answer here
Both nodes can respond. In active passive, only 1 node can respond since other is on standby.
Failover is when node switches to active / failed
Failback is when failed node returns to service

Per BING..A configuration in which both nodes of a redundant system respond to service requests whenever possible is called an active-active configuration 12. In this configuration, both nodes are active and can respond to service requests. This configuration provides high availability and redundancy in case of a failure of one of the nodes..sounds reasonable
